    <subfield code="t">CONTENTS; PREFACE; CHAPTER 1  GENERALITIES ON DYNAMIC SYSTEMS AND MAPS; 1.1. Continuous Dynamic Systems and Discrete Dynamic Systems.; 1.2. Some Definitions and Properties.; 1.8. Maps and the Schroder's Equatioa</subfield>
  </datafield>
  <datafield tag="505" ind1=" " ind2=" ">
    <subfield code="t">1.8.1. Generalities.1.8.2. Basin boundary, singular points and the Schroeder's equation.; 1.8.3. One-dimensional noninveriible maps and chaotic behaviours. Generalization of Chebyshev's polynomials.; 1.8.4. One-dimensional noninvertible maps. Properties of generalized Chebyshev's polynomials.; 1.8.5. One-dimensional noninvertible maps. Examples of functions HK giving rise to chaotic behaviors.; 1.8.6. Generalization to m-dimensional noninvertible maps m > 1.; CHAPTER 2  ONE-DIMENSIONAL NONINVERTIBLE MAPS; 2.1. Introduction.; 2.2. Critical points. Properties.; 2.2.1. Definitions.</subfield>
  </datafield>
  <datafield tag="505" ind1=" " ind2=" ">
    <subfield code="t">2.2.2. Different determinations of the inverse map.2.2.3. Folding of the real line. Definition of preimages. Generalities.; 2.3. Some Properties of One-Dimensional Maps.; 2.4. Other Definitions.; 2.5. Maps Defined by a Function with only one Extremum. Rotation Sequences and Boxes in Files Structures.; 2.5.1. Rotation sequences.; 2.5.2. Diffeomorphism of the circle. Fractal ""boxes in files"" bifurcation structure.; 2.5.3. Quadratic algebraic rotation numbers.; 2.6. Maps Defined by a Function With Only One Extremum. Fractal ""Box-Within-a-Box"" Bifurcation Structure; 2.6.1. Generalities.</subfield>
  </datafield>
  <datafield tag="505" ind1=" " ind2=" ">
    <subfield code="t">2.6.2. Properties and fundamental bifurcations of unimodal noninvertible maps.2.6.3. Succinct description of the ""box-within-a-box"" bifurcations structure.; 2.6.4.   </datafield>

Maps with several points of discontinuity.; CHAPTER 3  TWO-DIMENSIONAL NONINVERTIBLE MAPS. PROPERTIES OF CRITICAL CURVES; 3.1. Introduction.; 3.2. Critical curves. Types of Noninvertible Maps.; 3.2.1. Critical curves and inverses of a noninvertible map.</subfield>
  </datafield>
  <datafield tag="505" ind1=" " ind2=" ">
    <subfield code="t">3.2.2. Types of noninvertible maps with critical curves. Their symbolic representation.</subfield>
  </datafield>
  <datafield tag="520" ind1=" " ind2=" ">
    <subfield code="a">This book is essentially devoted to complex properties (Phase plane structure and bifurcations) of two-dimensional noninvertible maps, i.e. maps having either a non-unique inverse, or no real inverse, according to the plane point. They constitute models of sets of discrete dynamical systems encountered in Engineering (Control, Signal Processing, Electronics), Physics, Economics, Life Sciences. Compared to the studies made in the one-dimensional case, the two-dimensional situation remained a long time in an underdeveloped state.   <datafield tag="520" ind1=" " ind2=" ">
    <subfield code="a">Bowett's Law of International Institutions is the leading introduction to this complex, important and growing area of international law, with increasing significance for developments at the national level. Covering all the major global, regional and judicial institutions and all international organisations that regulate aspects of development and providing an introductory overview of the law of international organisations, including international courts and tribunals as a whole. The book offers a basic framework, insights into some of the more essential issues, and indications of where to find more detail. Bowett's is essential reading for students of international law and international relations and will also be of considerable interest to lawyers practising in the area.</subfield>
